nytimes_articles.abstract: SOCCER  U.S. Loses to Uruguay, 1-0, in America Cup  The United States, making its debut in the America Cup, the South American championship, lost by 1-0 to Uruguay yesterday before a capacity crowd of 20,000 in Ambato, Ecuador. Santiago Ostolaza scored on a header in the 50th minute against a United States squad that stayed with the Uruguayans most of the way but could not provide any finishing power around the net late in the game. In the second half, United States goalkeeper Brad Friedel saved a shot by Adrian Paz in the 47th minute. Ruben da Silva then hit the post in the 50th, Ostolaza -- unmarked during a corner kick -- delivered his header 30 seconds later. In another America Cup game last night, Colombia defeated Mexico, 2-1. (AP) Ireland Downs Lithuania on Ricochet Goal: Steve Staunton scored on a free kick in the 38th minute to lead Ireland to a 1-0 victory over Lithuania in a World Cup Group 3 qualifying match yesterday in Vilnius. Ireland is now the leader of the Group 3 with 15 points after nine matches. Staunton's shot ricocheted from defender Virginius Baltusnikas's leg past Lithuanian goalie Valdemaras Martin. Ireland, unbeaten, moved to the top of Group 3, with 15 points from nine games. The Irish will advance to the 24-nation finals with 4 points from its last three games. In other European games yesterday, Czechoslovakia beat the Faroe Islands, 3-0, in Group 4; Iceland downed Hungary, 2-0, in Group 5, and Finland drew, 0-0, with Israel in Group 6. In Asia, Iraq advanced to the second round of qualifying with a 3-0 victory over Yemen in Chengdu, China. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Angry U.S. Bike Team Says 'No' To Sharing Tour de France Slot
nytimes_articles.abstract: Angered by an offer to share a slot in the Tour de France, the Subaru-Montgomery team based in the United States decided Wednesday to skip the bicycle race. ."The team feels it deserves a full squad in the race, not a share in a combined team,&quo

nytimes_articles.headline: Barkley Confident the Suns Will Rise in Game 5
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley fell to one knee and gripped his shaved head not in agony, but in deep disappointment. He knew it was over.   It was in the final seconds of the fourth game of the National Basketball Association playoff finals at Chicago Stadium, and he had helped bring his Phoenix Suns back into contention, only to have Michael Jordan send them out of it.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Official Has Doubts About Pepsi Tampering
nytimes_articles.abstract: Consumers' complaints that they were finding syringes, hypodermic needles and other objects in cans of Pepsi-Cola continued to mount across the country today, but the nation's chief food and drug regulator expressed doubt that many of the reports, or even any, would prove valid.   The official, Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said in an interview that Federal investigators had been unable to confirm even one case of tampering among dozens of such reports that the Food and Drug Administration had received.

nytimes_articles.headline: Major League Baseball Moves Closer to Expanding Playoffs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Major league baseball appeared to move one step closer yesterday to expanding its post-season playoffs from two teams in each league to four for the 1994 season. But the Players Association indicated the proposed new format may not happen so quickly.   The owners' schedule format committee, meeting in Denver, voted 4-3 to recommend to the full ownership meeting today that a round be added to the playoffs, with the first-place team in each division playing the second-place team in a three-of-five-game series. The winners in that round then would play for the right to advance to the World Series.

nytimes_articles.headline: ESPN to Carry America's Cup
nytimes_articles.abstract: ESPN acquired the domestic and worldwide TV rights to the 1995 America's Cup yesterday, the fourth time it will carry the regatta. Coverage will include the Defender Series Finals in April and the America's Cup Match in May.   Two United States syndicates -- one led by Dennis Conner, the other by John Marshall -- have announced plans to enter the Defender Series.

nytimes_articles.headline: Braves Bury Schourek And Mets in the First
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Mets have spent the season making remarkable dramas of the most modest assignments.   Win a game? Oh, once in a while.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Commercial Run For Gurney's 'Later Life'
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Later Life," the A. R. Gurney play currently at Playwrights Horizons, will begin a commercial run Off Broadway in August.

nytimes_articles.headline: Search for Health-Research Director Narrows to 2
nytimes_articles.abstract: The field of candidates to fill the most prominent and influential post in biomedical research has been narrowed to two scientists who differ in virtually every professional particular beyond their ability to inspire zealous devotion from their advocates.   The finalists under consideration to serve as director of the National Institutes of Health are Dr. Harold E. Varmus of the University of California in San Francisco, a molecular biologist who has won wide fame and a Nobel Prize for his work in analyzing the genes that cause cancer, and Dr. Judith Rodin, the provost of Yale University and a psychologist known for her research on obesity and aging, Federal officials said.

nytimes_articles.headline: INQUIRY THREATENS A WHISTLE-BLOWER
nytimes_articles.abstract: A military whistle-blower is threatened with blacklisting by an Army investigation into his testimony to Congress about secret military programs, according to court documents and Pentagon officials.   The whistle-blower, William T. Golden, a 30-year veteran in Army intelligence work, has been sitting for three weeks with his wife, three children, four cats and two birds in a motel in Huntsville, Ala. He is barred from taking a post overseeing secret programs at the Air Force Intelligence Command in San Antonio, Pentagon officials say.

nytimes_articles.headline: Report Describes Jordan's Aid to Iraq During War
nytimes_articles.abstract: As King Hussein of Jordan prepares to meet for the first time with President Clinton on Friday, a Congressional report has confirmed that during the Persian Gulf war, Jordan was simultaneously receiving American military aid and helping Iraq by giving it American technolgy and intelligence information.    While many of the allegations about Jordan's cooperation with neighboring Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait and during the gulf war in 1991 have been known, the recently declassified report provides new concrete evidence about the depth of the relationship between the two countries, despite United Nations sanctions against Iraq.

nytimes_articles.headline: Minimum Tax Closes Corporate Loopholes
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Liberals Fight Clinton Plan to Ease Tax on Companies" (Business Day, June 10) states:

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Opera; Mozart in Which Machinery Is Minimal and Hell Madness
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Opera Theater of St. Louis finds itself at the edge of real operatic eminence in this country, and Sunday night's performance of "Don Giovanni" at Loretto-Hilton Center helped explain why the company has come so far and why it has not quite arrived.   Its best singers for this Mozart production arrive in pairs: Christopher Robertson and Thomas Barrett as the Don Giovanni and Leporello, the first smoothly convincing, the second with a boyish charm; then there are Christine Brewer and Patricia Racette, both powerful performers as the Donnas Anna and Elvira.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Choices in Bosnia : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The international community should face up honestly to the only two alternatives in Bosnia - arming and giving air support to the country's defenders, or acquiescing in a greater Serbia, with the competition of ethnic cleansing not only in Bosnia but in

nytimes_articles.headline: Bishops Step Into Furor Over Translation of Mass
nytimes_articles.abstract: A little-known Roman Catholic commission has stirred so much furor with its proposals to retranslate parts of the Mass that the National Conference of Catholic Bishops has set aside part of its semiannual meeting here to discuss the commission and how the bishops work with it.   The International Commission on English in the Liturgy, established in the 1960's after the Second Vatican Council opened the way to celebrating Mass in local languages instead of Latin, is completing the task of redoing the hurried translations of that time. Lately it has angered many conservative Catholics with proposals like these:

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Seeks to Protect Fruits Of Tax-Supported Research
nytimes_articles.abstract: Federal officials said today that they might take legal action against the country's largest private research institute because of its plan to sell all its discoveries, even those made with public money, to one pharmaceutical company for the next 20 years.   Officials of the National Institutes of Health on Friday notified the Scripps Research Institute, a private concern that gets both Federal and private money, that its proposed $300 million deal with the Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corporation was probably illegal and that the Government might take action to strip Scripps of its patent rights to any discoveries made with Federal money.

nytimes_articles.headline: Finding of 3d Body Raises More Questions About Ship
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the third time this week, the body of an Asian man believed to have been a passenger on a stricken vessel smuggling illegal Chinese immigrants was found yesterday morning floating off Fort Tilden Gateway Beach in Queens, authorities said.   If the Medical Examiner's office determines that the three bodies were from the ship, the Golden Venture, the death toll in the disaster would rise to nine. The ship foundered off the Rockaway Peninsula on June 6 with about 300 illegal Chinese immigrants aboard.

nytimes_articles.headline: Irremediable Damage : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "So Biodiversity is Doomed? Let's Take a Cool Recount" (Opinion, May 14): .The pretext of "no conclusive evidence" is often the excuse for inaction, which some myopic businessmen and politicians use for protecting their sh

nytimes_articles.headline: State to Investigate Case of Woman Left for Dead
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York State Health Department said yesterday that it would investigate an incident in which two New York City emergency medical technicians mistakenly pronounced a Brooklyn woman dead, leaving her without medical help for several hours.   The woman, Nancy Vitale, a 40-year-old parochial-school teacher, was in critical condition yesterday in the intensive-care unit of Coney Island Hospital, said Ken Kiernan, a hospital spokesman, although he added that she had regained consciousness and was speaking with doctors.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Tuesday about MacArthur Fellowship winners rendered the name of a University of Massachusetts professor incorrectly. He is John Edgar Wideman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bad Weather Forces Maple Syrup Crop to a Record Low
nytimes_articles.abstract: Maple syrup production in New York fell to a record low this year because of bad weather, the State Agricultural Statistics Service has reported .   For consumers, that may mean higher prices later this year, but several farmers said the shortage would probably be overcome by imports from Canada, which has a large surplus from last year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Advances in Detection Create Dilemma on Prostate Cancer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prostate cancer is being diagnosed at a higher rate than ever before, according to new data from the National Cancer Institute. And as more cancers are diagnosed, record numbers of men are undergoing radiation or operations to remove the prostate.   But no evidence exists to show that this aggressive effort to diagnose and treat the cancer has had any effect in improving survival. And most of the increase in diagnosis can be attributed to new, more advanced diagnostic techniques, researchers say. 16% Increase Reported    In fact, they say, more cancers are being caught at an earlier, more treatable stage. The real risk is in the treatment. Removal of the prostate not only has a higher death rate than comparable kinds of surgery, but it can also cause impotence and incontinence in large numbers of patients.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russia Aims Its Oil Weapon
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The conflicts in Russia between President Boris Yeltsin and his parliamentary opponents are extremely visible, but we should focus more on what they have in common: a strong desire to turn Russia and the other members of the Commonwealth of Independent States into a confederation and eventually a federation. For Russia, the next crucial step is tighter integration with Ukraine.

President Yeltsin's opponents -- the moderate Civic Union, which controls the Russian Congress, and the right-wing Communists -- openly call for a strong economic and security union within the Commonwealth. Mr. Yeltsin has the same goal, but for the last year he has been quietly pursuing a more subtle policy with the use of the oil weapon.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "An Energy Crisis Stalls Washington" (Opinion, May 27): .Considering all of the problems with an energy tax, many of the stated goals could be achieved in a much simpler fashion by raising automobile fuel efficiency standards from t

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I have been supportive of my wife since the beginning of time and she has been supportive of me. It's not sacrifice; it's family." -- MARTIN D. GINSBURG, whose wife, Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg, has been nominated to the Supreme Court.  [ A1:2. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Freeze!' and Other Helpful Phrases
nytimes_articles.abstract: Under pressure to keep other Japanese travelers from suffering the fate of a 16-year-old exchange student who was shot to death in Louisiana, the Government here has rushed to publish a small guide for Japanese headed to the United States, filled with helpful tourist phrases like "Hands in the air!"   As summer tourists head for the airports next month, Japan's Ministry of Transportation plans to distribute, through travel agents and airlines, several hundred thousand copies of the new guide to staying alive on America's mean streets. While the final version has yet to be set in type, its authors say they are combing the American vernacular for phrases that no Japanese should leave home without.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Wanted: Summer Jobs for Teens
nytimes_articles.abstract: The latest national figures show an increase in job growth and a slight easing of the unemployment rate, from 7 to 6.9 percent. But the picture is not so rosy for teen-agers, particularly urban youths.    Nationwide, about 20 percent of teen-agers are unemployed. However, New York City officials report that 40 percent of city teens were jobless during the first three months of this year. That's about twice the rate of just two years ago -- and the highest recorded level in 25 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tale of a Screening That Might Not Have Been
nytimes_articles.abstract: Movie studios and journalists are often like a warring married couple enduring a love-hate relationship: divorce is rare because each side needs the other to survive.   Yet Columbia Studios, a movie heavyweight in this town, has served notice on The Los Angeles Times, the town's newspaper heavyweight, that it is "out of business" starting on Monday unless The Times bars a reporter from covering the studio. Columbia executives are angry because of what one of them calls "an utterly irresponsible and untrue account" published in the paper about "Last Action Hero," the studio's big action-adventure summer movie opening on Friday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sex Disparity in Tests
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   John Beasley's concern about the science education of his two daughters in "Isn't Sex Disparity in Tests a National Scandal?" (letter, June 6) is justified. The disparity in scores between girls and boys was found in all 17 countries in which testing was done. But in one important set of test questions girls did as well as boys.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Window on Immigrant Crime; In Jackson Heights, Drugs, Dirty Money and Prostitution
nytimes_articles.abstract: No one knows how much criminal money flows through Jackson Heights, but no one doubts the current is steady and strong. On its busy and peaceful surface, the Queens neighborhood is like so many others where immigrants settle into new lives. People work hard, buy houses and shops and send money to the places they once called home.    Most of the enterprise is legal. But Jackson Heights is also the home to Little Colombia -- where high-level drug dealers operate and where much of their cash is laundered through travel agencies and wire transfer services that line Roosevelt Avenue in conspicuous numbers. By coincidence, the community is also the city's new capital for houses of prostitution.

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Leaders Propose Dividing Bosnia Into Three Areas
nytimes_articles.abstract: The leaders of Serbia and Croatia, the two most powerful republics in the old Yugoslav federation, today proposed scrapping the international plan for ending the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and offered one of their own.   President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia said the plan he and President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia were offering would preserve the nominal unity of the country. But in other respects the proposal described by Mr. Tudjman resembled the current situation on the ground: three separate ethnic areas, with Muslims confined to two separate landlocked pockets of territory, one around Sarajevo, Zenica and Tuzla and the other in the northwest around Bihac.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rail Link Would Cross The Hudson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Metro-North Commuter Railroad said yesterday that a bridge or tunnel across the Hudson River to link Rockland and Orange counties with Grand Central Terminal would pay for itself in revenues, commuting time saved and congestion and pollution reduced, even though it would cost up to $1.76 billion.   But the railroad rejected, at least for now, a bolder plan to continue the trans-Hudson tracks eastward across Westchester, through White Plains to Port Chester. Such a line would break the radial nature of the train system by connecting the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines, allowing people to move easily by train among suburbs and satellite cities rather than simply commuting in and out of Manhattan. But the railroad said that a train would draw only about 15 percent of the people who drive, because their destinations on the Westchester-Connecticut side are so diffuse.  Wanted: A Direct Route    In contrast, the railroad said, 60 percent of the people who commute to Manhattan from New York west of the Hudson during peak hours would do so by train if one were available that took a reasonably direct route. By way of comparison, the railroad said that in Westchester it captures 75 percent of those passengers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Now Read The Rules To Japan
nytimes_articles.abstract: At regular intervals, like the dance of the hours in the great clock towers of Central Europe, there is movement about Japan. Some bewail its steadily rising trade surplus with the West. Others canvass solutions. Still others point out that there is noth

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Blood and Irony
nytimes_articles.abstract: The lights may not be going out all over Europe, but the gates are surely slamming in the faces of immigrants and asylum-seekers.    As recession bites, xenophobes use foreigners as scapegoats. In France, a demeaning "zero immigration" is proclaimed as a goal; in Germany, the asylum law compensating the world for accepting refugees from Hitler has been repealed. Who gets the blame for unemployment, crime, homelessness? Outsiders.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Plan From Serbs and Croats   Serbian and Croatian leaders proposed scrapping the Bosnian peace plan and placing Muslims in two separate landlocked areas. Page A3. nytimes_articles.headline: Filibuster Is Ended by Accord On Campaign Financing Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senate Democrats made a series of deals today that all but assured passage of campaign-finance legislation that would impose voluntary spending limits but eliminate most of the public financing President Clinton had proposed.   After extracting concessions from the Democrats, 7 Republicans joined with 55 Democrats to end the nearly three weeks of debate on the bill. The vote was 62 to 37, or two more than necessary to break a Republican filibuster. A final vote is scheduled for Thursday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on the Media Business page yesterday, about the marketing of the television show "Beverly Hills, 90210," omitted the full name and affiliation of one of the people quoted. He was Robert Sigman, executive vice president and general manager of Worldvision Home Video Inc.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption yesterday with the obituary of John B. Connally incorrectly described a picture of him and President John F. Kennedy. The car in which the two men were sitting was not the limousine in which Kennedy was assassinated, but a smaller car they used earlier that day. The caption also misstated Mr. Connally's location in the later motorcade. He sat in a jump seat between the front and rear seats of the limousine, not in its front seat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A brief front-page summary yesterday about an Air Force general who was found to have disparaged President Clinton misstated the prospective disciplinary action in some copies. It is the Air Force, not the President, that plans to reprimand the officer, Maj. Gen. Harold N. Campbell.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Ballet; Mannerisms Of the 1800's Are Given Modern Flair
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Le Tombeau de Couperin," presented by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, is a ballet that seems to grow and deepen with almost every viewing. Though the piece was one of the few enduring works to come out of the company's 1975 Ravel Festival, it looked at first like a ravishingly pretty trifle, full of light, air, simplicity and order.   Created by George Balanchine for 16 City Ballet corps dancers, "Le Tombeau de Couperin" made it possible to savor the dancers' individual gifts and presences. At the same time, the dancers served almost symphonically to augment each formal pattern and courtly, gracious mannerism. Each was performed by a group split into two quadrilles, or ensembles.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; A Familiar Formula in a New Bottle
nytimes_articles.abstract: Going "Eye to Eye With Connie Chung" on the first edition of the new CBS magazine program tonight at 9 is Roger Clinton, the President's wayward half brother. Mr. Clinton, who did prison time a few years ago for trafficking in cocaine and was recently involved in an altercation at a Knicks-Bulls playoff game, is now performing as a rock singer, through the useful offices of big brother's Hollywood pals.   The nicely tuned combination of sympathy and skepticism with which Ms. Chung elicits the story of how Roger supposedly got the way he is reflects the spirit of the program and perhaps of the series. In tonight's second segment, Bernard Goldberg takes a similar attitude toward the family of a Marine colonel, James Sabow, who officials say committed suicide in 1991; his wife, children and brother maintain that he was murdered, probably by military brass trying to cover up their activities in the drug trade. And in the final segment, Edie Magnus commiserates with a California girl who complains of being called rude names by boys in school hallways, but Ms. Magnus also questions the seriousness of such goings on.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; Serial Killer With an Eye on His Image
nytimes_articles.abstract: In prison for life, a serial killer begins to collaborate on a book with a husband-and-wife team of journalists. The writers are revolted by the stories he tells them about his vicious killings and by the dispassion with which he speaks of his own brutality. Soon he infiltrates their nightmares. Like the Anthony Hopkins character in "The Silence of the Lambs," he may have a similar effect on theatergoers seeing Lee Blessing's "Down the Road" at the Atlantic Theater.   As portrayed by Eric Stoltz, the character is chillingly in control, manipulating his biographers to his purpose and strictly limiting what he will reveal. He readily tells them how he committed his crimes but is closely guarded about his reasons. He makes a point of saying that he is a serial killer not a serial murderer, because murderers have motives and his acts were without provocation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Let's Stop Using 'Liberal' as a Dirty Word
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 6 front-page report of a New York Times/CBS News poll finding that most Americans view President Clinton as "liberal" was incomplete and carried a hidden bias. While the poll indicates a growing perception of the President as liberal, another message seeps through: "liberal" as negative.

nytimes_articles.headline: Taylor Is in Rare Form: He Attends a Mini-Camp
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lawrence Taylor had mentioned his off-season preference for putting greens over artificial turf, but two days after his new coach sharply criticized him for failing to attend the team's mini-camp, Taylor dropped his clubs and showed up today at Giants Stadium for the team's third and final session.    Taylor, looking fit in street clothes, said he last attended a mini-camp in 1982 though he did appear in 1986 for a physical. The linebacker met with Coach Dan Reeves for about 15 minutes to clear up what the 10-time Pro Bowl performer termed a misunderstanding between the two. The 34-year-old outside linebacker missed the final seven games last season with a severed right Achilles' tendon, then signed a contract he had agreed to two months earlier, for a reported $5.05 million for 1993 and 1994.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: For 14 years, PAT SALVAGGIONE has watched the world go by from the 58th Street entrance of Bergdorf Goodman, helping customers with packages and finding them taxis. For 30 years before that, he did the same cheerful doorman's duty at Bonwit Teller. He refused repeated entreaties from Bergdorf's until Bonwit Teller closed its Fifth Avenue store in 1979.    This afternoon, Bergdorf's colleagues and clients plan to gather and raise a glass of Champagne to send him into retirement.

nytimes_articles.headline: Baker and Johnson Clear Air on Comments
nytimes_articles.abstract: San Francisco Giants Manager DUSTY BAKER, disturbed about possible racial implications in a comment attributed to DAVEY JOHNSON about inexperienced managers getting jobs, asked the new Cincinnati Reds manager about it. Baker said he had heard that Johnson said he couldn't understand why men like Baker, former Reds Manager TONY PEREZ and DON BAYLOR of the Colorado Rockies were landing major league jobs while Johnson had no job offers for three years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Franco the Raging Met
nytimes_articles.abstract: John Franco's right hand looked like a baseball, stitches tracing their way across knuckles. His right hand, though, doesn't have to throw a baseball. Thus there was more a sense of humor than regret in the clubhouse today concerning Franco's latest outburst.   The left-handed closer for the Mets split his knuckles after hitting an undisclosed object in frustration Tuesday night, but he was declared available to pitch by Manager Dallas Green.

nytimes_articles.headline: Prospect Park to Have Even Less Safety Under New Zoo Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The recent spate of tragic crimes in Brooklyn's beautiful Prospect Park, including the shooting death of Allyn Winslow while fending off efforts to steal his bicycle, raises an urgent question:

nytimes_articles.headline: FINANCIER IN INDIA ACCUSES PREMIER
nytimes_articles.abstract: A powerful Indian financier, who is the main figure in a billion-dollar banking and securities scandal, said today that he had paid a bribe of more than 10 million rupees, or about $300,000, to Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao to secure political backing.   Mr. Rao, who has held office for two years, strongly denied the charge today, saying he was "shocked and pained" by it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Met Opera; 'Butterfly' Opens Free Concerts in Parks
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Metropolitan Opera's annual contribution to the urban summer is a series of free concerts in parks in the five boroughs and New Jersey. This year's run, which opened with Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" on the Great Lawn of Central Park on Tuesday evening, is the Met's 27th season of outdoor performing.   The Met's park concerts have traditionally been sponsored by a corporation, typically a bank. This year the series is being paid for with a $1.9 million grant from the Lila Acheson and DeWitt Wallace Fund for Lincoln Center.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Party Joins the Salk Addition Dispute
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Federal Advisory Council on Historic Preservation has joined a protracted dispute over an addition to the Salk Institute for Biological Sciences, the landmark building in La Jolla, Calif., designed by Louis I. Kahn. The Advisory Council voted last week to ask Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, to investigate whether the addition has received Federal assistance. Although construction on the addition is under way, the council's action could open the way for a formal review of its design.   The addition is being built on a site formerly occupied by a eucalyptus grove that formed a landscaped entrance to the laboratory complex. Since the institute unveiled the plan two years ago, it has been criticized by architects and historians who regard the Salk complex as one of the most important buildings of the 20th century and maintain that the landscaped setting is integral to Kahn's design.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHINA WINS FIGHT ON RIGHTS GROUPS
nytimes_articles.abstract: In what was seen as a victory for China's campaign to limit international monitoring of human rights, nongovernmental organizations attending the World Conference on Human Rights were ejected today from the committee drafting the meeting's final document.   The nongovernmental organizations, which include powerful groups like Amnesty International, protested angrily that the United Nations had allowed itself to be browbeaten by China, which had threatened to boycott the drafting committee if independent human rights representatives were present.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yeltsin, Near Accord, Pushes Work on Constitution
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin today extended for another 10 days the assembly he called to discuss a new constitution, saying there were grounds to declare that "a single, agreed draft of a new constitution is being born."   Mr. Yeltsin told delegates to continue working in committees and to meet together on June 26. "In principle, everything is moving at such a pace that we should actually finish our work in June and move on to early parliamentary elections," he said, adding that they could be held in September.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Treat Air Quality in Planes as a Luxury
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   One step forward, two steps back. I was astonished to read "Frequent Fliers Saying Fresh Air Is Awfully Thin at 30,000 Feet" (front page, June 6), on the reduction of circulation of fresh air on newer airplanes. Just as we were permitted to breathe more freely when smoking was eliminated on short flights, we learn that the quality of the air in the cabins has been decreased.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 25 1/2-Hour German Epic of Discovery and Art
nytimes_articles.abstract: The statistics are daunting. The German director Edgar Reitz's 25 1/2-hour epic film, "Heimat II: Chronicle of a Generation," has 2,143 pages of script and consumed more than a million feet of exposed film. It took six years to write, 557 days to shoot and 117 days to edit. The cast includes 71 leading roles, 310 smaller ones and 2,300 extras.    The product of this prodigious teamwork is an alternately gripping and lyrical 13-episode serial about German life in the 1960's that is being shown in roughly four-hour installments at the Joseph Papp Public Theater through July 29. Handsomely photographed and superbly acted, with English subtitles and a remarkably evocative soundtrack, it might be the ultimate highbrow soap opera for couch potatoes except that there are no plans to show "Heimat II" on television in the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Starring in Tocqueville's Crystal Ball
nytimes_articles.abstract: Commager on Toqueville By Henry Steele Commager 130 pages. University of Missouri Press. $24.95.   Henry Steele Commager's brilliant new interpretation of Alexis de Tocqueville's "Democracy in America" offers this astute comment: "He had an instinct for the jugular vein in history."

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Optioned John Farrell, pitcher, to Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. Recalled Hilly Hathaway, pitcher, from Vancouver.   CHICAGO WHITE SOX -- Placed Kirk McCaskill, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 15. Purchased the contract of Scott Ruffcorn, pitcher, from Birmingham of the Southern League. Signed Gregory Norton and Benjamin Boulware, infielders.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Unyielding AIDS Epidemic
nytimes_articles.abstract: The international AIDS conference in Berlin last week left a depressing message: no scientific breakthrough is apt to wipe this scourge from the earth any time soon. Indeed, the existing medical weapons against AIDS are less successful than once believed. There is little choice now but to shift the emphasis to prevention programs.   The drug AZT, long the mainstay of AIDS treatment, has only limited value for a limited time -- and is highly toxic to boot. Worse yet, it apparently has little or no effect when given to people who are infected with the virus but have not yet developed symptoms. That dashes the hopes of millions of infected individuals that early treatment might ward off death.

nytimes_articles.headline: Of Brodkey and AIDS: Laugh a Bit, Cry a Bit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even in the best of times, Harold Brodkey can be difficult. He tends to turn the tables on an interviewer, spending more time asking questions than answering them. He probes. He ponders. He plays.   So it should come as good news to members of the cultlike Brodkey following -- the fans of his books and his New Yorker articles -- that despite his announcement in the magazine this week that he has AIDS, he remains true to form.

nytimes_articles.headline: Baltusrol Blueprint: Drive It Straight And Drive It Long
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the eve of the first round of the 93d United States Open, here at Baltusrol, 156 players went to bed massaging their psyches for the most ego-deflating test in golf.   But although it is the most nerve-racking, demanding and arguably the most important of golf's four major championships, the United States Open is often the least exciting.

nytimes_articles.headline: Future Doctors Hold Memorial for 'First Patients'
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT had all the trappings of a traditional memorial service. There were remembrances of the departed, prayers, floral arrangements and even organ music, albeit from a portable synthesizer.   But there was one distinguishing feature of the somber gathering that took place today at New York Medical College in Valhalla. The departed that were being honored were cadavers -- the bodies that had been used by first-year medical students in their introductory gross medical anatomy class.

nytimes_articles.headline: Science Education Must Discover Real World
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As a graduate of the California Institute of Technology, I share the pain of the capable young men and women who find their futures clouded by the uncertainty in science and engineering careers (front page, June 6). Caltech and its sister institutions are in trouble. The roots of this problem are deep.

nytimes_articles.headline: Republican Tax-Cut Plan May Be Political Problem
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Republican Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, has drafted legislation to cut the state income tax beginning next year -- a proposal with tricky political implications in this election year.   A permanent cut in state income taxes would introduce a new dimension into campaign politics. Ordinarily, a tax cut would seem a boon for a governor and state legislators seeking re-election.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Troubled Life Ends
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a sense, Johnny Ray Cromartie never really left his old neighborhood. In 1971, his mother moved the family out of its apartment at 147th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Harlem, but Johnny kept going back.   It was in that neighborhood, dotted with trash-strewn vacant lots and buildings long missing their window panes, that he had most of his numerous run-ins with the law in the 1970's. People in the area recall that in recent years, a time when he stayed out of trouble, the heavy-set, soft-spoken man still came around regularly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigeria Suspends Results of Vote That Was to Restore Democracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nigeria's planned return to civilian rule was suspended today when a commission appointed by the military leaders set aside the results of Saturday's presidential elections.   There had been growing indications that the candidate of the Social Democratic Party, Moshood Abiola, was well on his way to a resounding triumph over his rival, Bashir Tofa, of the National Republican Convention. Both had campaigned against military rule.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mideast Peace: Close but Stuck
nytimes_articles.abstract: Israel and Syria agree in principle on swapping Golan Heights land for peace, though they don't yet agree on how much land and what kind of peace. Israeli and Jordanian negotiators are even closer to agreement and talks between Israel and Lebanon are making modest progress.    Even on the Israel-Palestinian front there are constructive new proposals, with Israel now offering to transfer some local government powers immediately, even before concluding a formal autonomy agreement.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sharks Name Youngest Coach in N.H.L.
nytimes_articles.abstract: The San Jose Sharks named KEVIN CONSTANTINE as the team's coach yesterday. Constantine, 33, spent the last two seasons as coach of the Kansas City Blades, the Sharks' International Hockey League affiliate. He becomes the youngest coach in the 26-team National Hockey League. The Sharks went 11-71-2, breaking the record for most single-season losses.

nytimes_articles.headline: Blame the Filibusterers : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the Republicans staged a filibuster in the Senate last month you let them off much too lightly. Instead of saying how appallingly undemocratic a filibuster is, your writers seemed to interpret it as weakness in President Bill Clinton. Why not put th

nytimes_articles.headline: Somali Clan Chief Poses Tough Problem for U.N.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five days after United States warplanes first attacked the radio station and arms depots of Mohammed Farah Aidid, the Somalia warlord held responsible for the killing of some 23 Pakistani United Nations troops, the question being raised by diplomats here is not whether he should be arrested, but what to do about him if he is detained.   Arresting and trying criminals is completely uncharted territory for the United Nations, and although American officials last Friday said Mr. Aidid would be apprehended, he has openly mocked the United Nations and the United States by appearing in public, almost daring them to seize him.

nytimes_articles.headline: Maximum Term in Gap Employee's Murder
nytimes_articles.abstract: The man convicted in the January 1992 murder of the assistant manager of a midtown Manhattan children's clothing store was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison.   Calling the murder "a crime that was heinous beyond comprehension," Acting Justice Harold J. Rothwax sentenced Anwar Abdul, 20, a former store employee, to the maximum under state law. The minimum sentence for murder is 15 years to life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Disputes Grow After Arrests of Yonkers Schoolchildren
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everyone agrees that a boy and girl got in an argument Friday on the playground of a west-side elementary school here. School officials described the gang-up that happened next as "roughhousing"; the police say it was sexual abuse.   On Tuesday, eight students, ages 9 to 13, were arrested and charged with sexual abuse and assault, both misdemeanors.

nytimes_articles.headline: Less Indifferent, the U.S. Is Year From Cup
nytimes_articles.abstract: In precisely one year -- June 17, 1994 -- the World Cup soccer tournament will strike the shores of the United States with the impact of an uncharted hurricane.   The sheer scale of the extravaganza will be stunning to those Americans who are not prepared for it: A total of 3.5 million spectators will fill the nine stadiums selected as the host sites for the monthlong tournament, with every ticket purchased well in advance. And about 31 billion people, worldwide, will watch the event on television, living and suffering with every raised offside flag.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Treat Air Quality in Planes as a Luxury; Getting Off the Ground
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As a former airline executive, author of two books on the airline industry and industry consultant, I am concerned by the rumblings emanating from the 90-day airline commission headed by Gerald Baliles, former Virginia governor.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Intensifies Attack to Oust A Somali Clan
nytimes_articles.abstract: United States and allied forces mounted a major strike tonight against the leader of the dominant Somali faction in an effort to destroy his base of operations in Mogadishu and rout him from his headquarters.   United States officials said the aim of the air and ground attack on the commander, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, was to end his ability to disrupt United Nations operations and to eliminate him as a factor in Somali politics.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Reagan Years : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Bobby Kennedy Did Care, and It Made a Difference" (Opinion, June 1) by Anthony Lewis: .Mr. Lewis deplores the divisions in our society, blaming, as usual, President Ronald Reagan. Most Americans believed the Reagan years to be an e

nytimes_articles.headline: Kohl Plans to Ease the Path for New Citizens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to growing pressure after fatal attacks on Turks here, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced new steps today that will make German citizenship easier to obtain.   Many longtime foreign residents of Germany, including Turks who have spent most of their lives here and their children who were born here, complain that German laws keep them from becoming citizens. Mr. Kohl made clear today that he sympathizes with these complaints, though he did not say precisely what new formula he would favor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Du Pont Plans Inquiry on Pesticide Crop Damage
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stung by accusations that it was concealing information about extensive crop damage caused by one of its pesticides, the nation's largest chemical company said yesterday that it would conduct an internal investigation of whether the charges were true.   But Edgar S. Woolard Jr., the chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that he would defy a subpoena issued last week by the Florida Commissioner of Agriculture to testify about the pesticide in Tallahassee on July 20.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK CITY  ARREST MADE IN SLAYING   A Brooklyn man has been arrested in the killing of a 16-year-old student near a school for the emotionally disturbed, a shooting that the police said was carried out despite the victim's pleas for mercy. The suspect, Gregory Gooding, 21 years old, is also wanted for questioning in another shooting, in a housing project. B3. BLAST SUSPECT RETAINS HIS LAWYERS   Mahmud Abouhalima, a major suspect in the World Trade Center bombing, has told a judge that he was dissatisfied with his lawyers but stopped short of dismissing them. His decision followed conversations in which Mr. Abouhalima had said that he wanted to change lawyers, which spurred new talk that he might become a cooperating witness. B3. STATE INVESTIGATION IN E.M.S. CASE   The New York State Health Department says it will investigate an incident in which two New York City emergency medical technicians mistakenly pronounced a Brooklyn woman dead, leaving her without medical aid for several hours. Emergency Medical Service officials have cleared the two technicians of any wrongdoing and said that the technicians had followed state procedures. B2. REGION  TAX CUT IS PROPOSED   The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, a Republican, has drafted legislation to cut the state income tax beginning next year -- a proposal with tricky political implications. B7. PLAYGROUND FIGHT CALLED SEXUAL ABUSE   Everyone agrees that a boy and girl got in an argument Friday on the playground of a west side Yonkers elementary school. School officials described the gang-up that happened next as "roughhousing." The police, however, say it was a case of sexual abuse. B7. THOSE WHO DONATE BODIES ARE HONORED   There was one distinguishing feature of the somber gathering that took place today at New York Medical College in Valhalla. The departed that were being honored were cadavers -- the bodies that had been used by first-year medical students in their introductory gross medical anatomy class. Vahalla Journal. B7. METRO-NORTH BACKS HUDSON CROSSING   Metro-North Commuter Railroad says that a bridge or tunnel across the Hudson River to link Rockland and Orange counties with Grand Central Terminal would pay for itself in revenues, commuting time saved and congestion and pollution reduced, even though it would cost up to $1.76 billion. But the railroad rejected, at least for now, a bolder plan to continue the trans-Hudson tracks eastward across Westchester, through White Plains to Port Chester. B7. D'AMATO OUTBURST IS DESCRIBED   Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato poked his finger into Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine's chest and shouted obscenities at him during a rally at the Plattsburgh Air Force Base, Plattsburgh's Mayor has said. B6. Maple syrup production in New York fell to a record low this year because of bad weather, the State Agricultural Statistics Service says. B6. Chronicle B5

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Taming Toxic Goop
nytimes_articles.abstract: Who says New Yorkers don't recycle? On a recent blustery Sunday, 275 Brooklynites bearing hazardous waste arrived by car and on foot at an exquisitely appropriate site -- a parking lot overshadowed by the blackened smokestacks of the Greenpoint incinerator and sandwiched between the settling tanks of the Newtown Creek sewage plant.    There they surrendered to the city's Department of Sanitation substances like oven cleaners and flammable solvents as well as seemingly innocuous garbage like household batteries, nail polish, art supplies and mothballs. When tossed in the regular trash, such products have been known to burn sanitation workers, set small fires in garbage trucks and seep out of the Fresh Kills landfill into surface water.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart in SportsWednesday yesterday about the Yankees' victory over the Boston Red Sox incorrectly described the way New York scored its last three runs in an eight-run fifth inning. Paul O'Neill's single to right field scored Jim Leyritz and Danny Tartabull. Dave Silvestri's single to left scored Mike Stanley.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: Axis Peace Feelers : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - [From our New York edition:] Two new, roundabout Axis peace feelers were reported today [June 16] while the Allied war of nerves continued unabated, stinging Berlin into boasting of the security of its Balkan bastions on the eastern Mediterranean

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Wins Key Votes on Plan For Service Tied to School Loans
nytimes_articles.abstract: With overwhelming bipartisan support, Senate and House committees today approved President Clinton's national service program to enlist volunteers to do social, law-enforcement and environmental work in return for payments toward education loans.   Democrats and Republicans harkened back to the initiation of the Peace Corps and Vista (for Volunteers in Service to America) in the 1960's as they voted for a program designed to spur community spirit, broaden access to higher education and engage new graduates in socially useful work.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Inside Pitch on Brawls? It's the Inside Pitch
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cal Ripken Jr. almost sat out a game June 7, something he hasn't done since May 29, 1982.   Why? The day before, the Baltimore Orioles' iron-man shortstop had hurt his ankle in a brawl between his club and the Seattle Mariners.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooklyn Man Held in Killing of Youth, 16
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Brooklyn man has been arrested in the killing of a 16-year-old student near a school for the emotionally disturbed, a shooting that the police said was carried out despite the victim's pleas for mercy.   The suspect, Gregory Gooding, 21 years old, is also wanted for questioning in another shooting in a housing project near where he lived, which is about half a mile from the school where the student was shot.

nytimes_articles.headline: Atom Smasher Is Super Nonsense
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"Boondoggle" is a relatively new American word. Originally a braided leather lanyard worn by Boy Scouts, in the 1930's it was applied by critics of the New Deal to "useless tasks performed by recipients of its doles."

The proposed supercollider in Texas, at $8.4 billion, may be one of the greatest boondoggles of all time. But the main problem concerns something more fundamental than cost.

nytimes_articles.headline: St. John's Extends Mahoney's Contract
nytimes_articles.abstract: BRIAN MAHONEY, voted coach of the year in the Big East Conference in his first season as LOU CARNESECCA's replacement, was given a seven-year contract extension by St. John's yesterday.   Mahoney coached St. John's to a 19-11 record and second place in the conference in what was supposed to be a rebuilding season. The Redmen made the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament where they lost to Arkansas, 80-74.

nytimes_articles.headline: SENATORS ON FINANCE PANEL REACH ACCORD ON A BUDGET WITH GAS TAX AND NEW CUTS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Democratic senators on the Finance Committee agreed today on a set of new tax increases and spending cuts, pushing deficit-reduction legislation one step closer to becoming law.   The agreement, struck after days of agonizing bargaining, incorporates much of what President Clinton proposed and the House of Representatives approved last month. But it differs from the President's plan in important respects.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918:Italian Applause : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ROME - Speaking in the Chamber to-day [June 16] Signor Scipari said: "Yesterday we lost only two aeroplanes, compared with 32 lost by the enemy. In the name of this assemblyI express gratitude to the Flying Corps." (Loud applause.) Signor Chiesa

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Open Open To Pro Tour Winners
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE United States Open, which begins today at Baltusrol, is the world's best golf tournament. But it could be even better.   All the big names will be teeing off: Kite, Faldo, Langer, Azinger, Ballesteros, Stewart, Couples, Woosnam, Norman, Price, Daly, Strange, Olazabal, Pavin, Love, Lyle. So will the other fascinating foreign names: Montgomerie, Ozaki, Els, Singh. And so will most of the revered names: Nicklaus, Watson, Irwin, Floyd.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An entry in the Finance Briefs listing in Business Day on Tuesday misidentified a company that issued $200 million in notes, and misstated the location of its headquarters. It was the Primerica Corporation, which is based in New York, not its defunct subsidiary, Primerica Finance, in Baltimore.

nytimes_articles.headline: 57 Pupils in Queens Sickened by Heat
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fifty-seven elementary students fell ill with heat exhaustion yesterday during a graduation rehearsal in a Queens intermediate school auditorium, the police said.   The students, fifth graders from Public School 19 in Corona, were taken to six hospitals, where they were treated for stomachaches, dizziness and nausea and released. The youngsters had walked half a mile from their school to the auditorium at Leonardo da Vinci Intermediate School 61 in Corona for the rehearsal, said John Falco, deputy superintendent for District 24, Queens. After 40 minutes, Mr. Falco said some of the students grew faint. The high temperature yesterday in New York City was 84 degrees.

nytimes_articles.headline: EMPIRE SAYS DATA ON INSURANCE LOSS WERE ERRONEOUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield acknowledged yesterday that the company had repeatedly sent erroneous reports about its finances to New York State insurance regulators. The action came as state officials accused Empire's executives of obstructing state insurance examiners for years.   Kevin Foley, New York's deputy insurance superintendent, said Empire's executives made "misstatements" to the Insurance Department, told "falsehoods" and were slow to provide information requested by insurance examiners. Sometimes they claimed information did not exist, when it did, he said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rival Parties in Cambodia Agree To Form a Coalition Government
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cambodia's two major political parties agreed today to put aside years of brutal conflict to share power in an interim government that will almost certainly be led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the 70-year-old former monarch.   The power-sharing arrangement between the political arm of the current Vietnamese-installed Government and the royalist opposition party may mean an end, for now, to the chaos that last week produced a secessionist movement among several eastern provinces and the threat of an expanded civil war.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rally Assails Inquiries Into Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: About 1,500 people attended a rally in City Hall Park yesterday to protest what they called unacceptable delays in the investigations of racial disturbances in Crown Heights two summers ago.   Although billed as a nonpartisan rally, the demonstration was dominated by supporters of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor, and the tenor of Mr. Giuliani's remarks suggested he would continue to raise the Crown Heights issue throughout the mayoral campaign.

nytimes_articles.headline: Agents Says 49ers' Young Won't Jump
nytimes_articles.abstract: STEVE YOUNG's agent yesterday played down reports that the San Francisco 49ers quarterback might take advantage of his free-agent status to jump to another team.   LEIGH STEINBERG said free-agency restrictions make it unlikely Young will sign with anyone else.   "This form of free agency means Steve is about as free as the People's Republic of China," he said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Retired Police Officer Shoots Man in Yankee Stadium Lot
nytimes_articles.abstract: A retired police officer shot a man trying to steal a car from one of the Yankee Stadium parking lots during Tuesday night's game against the Boston Red Sox, the police said. The suspect was wounded in the left wrist and arrested, they said.   Security in parking lots at the stadium is one of several issues that George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, has brought before Mayor David N. Dinkins as Mr. Steinbrenner considers moving the Yankees out of the Bronx.

nytimes_articles.headline: Langer May Miss U.S. Open
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bernhard Langer, the Masters champion, had severe stiffness in his neck today and may be unable to play here at Baltusrol in the 1993 United States Open, which starts Thursday.   Langer said he strained his neck during practice Tuesday and went through three hours of physical therapy that night. But he awoke in pain today and was only able to chip and putt during the day. He spent most of the late afternoon in the PGA Tour's fitness trailer, where he was given massage and ultrasound treatment, but had seen little improvement by the time he left the course.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Inside Story : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: As to why Americans do not eat innards (American Topics, May 24) there is one simple reason: they are slimy and unappetizing! End of story.

nytimes_articles.headline: Campaign Bill Clears Hurdle
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senators made a series of deals that ended a Republican filibuster on campaign-finance legislation, all but assuring its passage. Page A20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hurt O'Brien Wins Decathlon; Joyner-Kersee Wheezes and Breezes in Heptathlon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Having fouled twice today on his first two discus throws, Dan O'Brien stood again at the decathlon precipice.   A cockier O'Brien, the one who no-heighted last year in the pole vault at the Olympic Trials and never made it to Barcelona, Spain, might have spun crazily around and attempted one last Herculean hurl. He might have fouled, been disqualified, and lost his invitation to the world track and field championships at Stuttgart, Germany, in August.

nytimes_articles.headline: What They're Reading
nytimes_articles.abstract: Abdurrahman Wahid, head of Nahdlatul Ulama, the largest Muslim organization in Indonesia, is reading "India: A Million Mutinies Now" by V.S. Naipaul. . Naipaul's "insights are valuable because Indonesia is another huge nation trying to int

nytimes_articles.headline: Home Video
nytimes_articles.abstract: ``Brady Bunch'' meets ``Arachnophobia.'' Baby dinosaurs and farm family. Cuddly and gentle.

nytimes_articles.headline: 4 Convicted of Attempted Murder of Bishop
nytimes_articles.abstract: Four men were convicted of attempted murder in Brooklyn yesterday in the attack on a Greek Orthodox Bishop last year, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn said.   The four men, aged 18 to 20, each pleaded guilty to trying to kill Bishop Alexios Panagiotopoulos during an attempted robbery outside his home in Crown Heights on Feb. 26, 1992, Mr. Hynes said. The maximum prison term for the crime is 8 1/3 to 25 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Capital Press and the President: Fair Coverage or Unreined Adversity?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Though mutual distrust is routine in Washington, President Clinton's conflicts with reporters have raised, somewhat earlier than usual, the question that arises in every Administration: whether the nation's news organizations are being fair to the President.   For months now, the press has had little good to say about President Clinton, and he has sometimes been unable to contain his obvious frustration with the press.

nytimes_articles.headline: Armenian Units Press Attack in Azerbaijan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Armenian forces in the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh are continuing an assault on a western Azerbaijani city and are close to encircling it, military officials said today.    More than 100 soldiers and civilians were reported killed in an attack today on the city, Agdam. There was no independent confirmation of the toll.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: EVAN STEADMAN, the producer and the lyricist of a musical based on the life of Robert Maxwell, the publishing tycoon who died at sea in 1991, vowed yesterday that the show would go on, despite the threat of legal action by KEVIN MAXWELL, Mr. Maxwell's younger son.    "Maxwell: the Musical," a comedy with lyrics set to familiar tunes by Gilbert and Sullivan, is scheduled to open in the West End, London's theater district, in November, two years after Mr. Maxwell's death.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yesterday's editorial on women as prime ministers misidentified the Governor General of Canada. He is Ramon John Hnatyshyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Looking the Other Way : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "It's Their Balkan Quarrel" (Opinion, June 2): .José Cutileiro blurs significant distinctions, makes Bosnian Muslims look as guilty of atrocities as Bosnian Serbs, sidesteps the central fact of direct involvement by Serbia and

nytimes_articles.headline: Cash Woes Cast A Long Shadow Over California
nytimes_articles.abstract: In years past during budget-making season, Tom Orloff, the chief assistant district attorney here, would amble across the street to the Alameda County administration building and plead, wheedle and threaten until he got enough money for his department to survive.    But this year, Mr. Orloff said, "even if we fight and scratch and claw on the county level, we'll still get killed" because of Gov. Pete Wilson's plan to balance the state's $52 billion budget by commandeering $2.6 billion in local property taxes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Showalter Loses His Cool and Yanks Lose the Game
nytimes_articles.abstract: Buck Showalter waved his arms. He kicked the dirt. He screamed. And he tried ejecting an umpire after he had already been thrown out of the game for arguing a controversial call. It does not work that way. Sweat poured off his face and his mouth flapped on, but the Yankee manager did not secure the result he desired. Neither did the Yankees.   Showalter trudged into the clubhouse, frustrated and frazzled because what apparently was a bunt single by Bernie Williams in the third inning was called a foul ball.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Approves Ban On Shipments of Oil To Haitian Military
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations Security Council voted today to impose a worldwide ban on oil shipments to Haiti but backed away from authorizing the United States or other countries to enforce the ban with a naval blockade.   The sanctions, which were approved unanimously, are aimed at forcing Haitian military leaders to accept the return of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. They were weakened in response to objections by Brazil to a clause that called for the inspection of ships trying to enter Haitian ports.

nytimes_articles.headline: Agreement On Stiffening License Laws
nytimes_articles.abstract: Legislative leaders said today that they had agreed to stiffen penalties on motorists caught driving with suspended licenses. For the first time, authorities would be able to bring felony charges against the most serious repeat offenders.   The legislation, in a slightly tougher form, was first recommended by the New York City Police Department, which was reacting to three recent, highly publicized incidents in which pedestrians were killed by drivers who had long records of license suspensions or who had no licenses at all.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Man Behind the High Court Nominee
nytimes_articles.abstract: In 1980, a handful of Republican senators appeared to be reluctant to confirm another Carter appointment to a Federal Court in an election year, so the prospective judge's husband mentioned the problem to a client.   The husband, Martin D. Ginsburg, told the client, Ross Perot, along with other influential friends in academic and political and corporate circles.

nytimes_articles.headline: Report's Proposals Due Today
nytimes_articles.abstract: The long-awaited and often-delayed report by the Governor's Advisory Commission on Racing in the 21st Century will finally be released today, and racing people are speculating that it might take until the 21st century to implement its proposals.   The report is subtitled "A Plan to Reform, Restructure and Revitalize the Horse Racing, Parimutuel Wagering and Breeding Industry in New York State," but it has already touched off controversies that might require action in the Legislature or the courts to resolve.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: The Budget; Democrats Pushing Plan Toward a Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shrugging off Republican accusations that they were raising taxes and cutting services for millions of Americans, the 11 Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee today started muscling the first big chunk of President Clinton's budget toward a Senate vote and enactment into law.   Tonight, Mr. Clinton focused on shielding his budget from further attacks within his own party. At a televised news conference, he said he was "drawing the line" on more concessions to conservatives in Congress who, he said, would lower the deficit by cutting deeply into Federal benefit programs rather than taking the money from the well-off.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Family Fun Run'   Central Park  97th Street and East Drive  (212) 860-4455  Recommended ages: 2 and up  Sunday    If you're a father who's always on the run, an organized race may be the chance to seize a fast-track moment with your family this weekend. At this family run, children as young as 2 can compete, starting in an energetic 50-yard dash.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: The listing of lottery results yesterday omitted a number in some copies for New York Pick 10. The complete Pick 10 numbers appear today, on page B2.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; Do Gods Get Angry?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Do you ever get angry at them?    I had wondered about that, before I had a chance to put the question -- whether the man whom millions love as a god allowed himself anger at those who slaughter his people and their nationhood.   He did, said the Dalai Lama, in his earlier years of exile. But he found that his anger weakened him, drained him, in his struggles against the Chinese Communists who had invaded, taken over and brutalized Tibet. So no, he did not get angry anymore.

nytimes_articles.headline: President, in Prime Time, Is Spurned by 2 Networks
nytimes_articles.abstract: After weeks of awkward stumbles and generally bad news, President Clinton hit a run of good luck this week that was timed so propitiously that his advisers decided that the President was ready for prime time.   But two of the three broadcast networks decided otherwise.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Base Closings; Aspin Asks Base-Closing Panel Not to Add to List
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Les Aspin today told a Presidential commission studying base closings that shutting down more than he recommended could hurt military readiness and overwhelm Pentagon efforts to help communities find new uses for closed sites.    Mr. Aspin's cautionary tone was in striking contrast to his first appearance before the commission on March 15, when he acknowledged that his list was based on outdated assumptions of the military's future size, and all but invited the panel to close several more installations.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sweep Nets 2 Scofflaws At the Wheel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two drivers whose licenses the police said had each been suspended more than 200 times were arrested this week, the latest of more than 1,500 motorists taken into custody under a two-month-old crackdown.   The two were stopped for minor traffic violations: one made a turn without signaling, the other took an illegal shortcut through a service station parking lot. But when the officers who pulled them over ran computer checks on their licenses, they discovered that the two had been stopped time and again but had never appeared in court.

nytimes_articles.headline: Governor Florio Prunes a Fig Leaf
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gov. Jim Florio's ban on blind trusts for New Jersey's public-office holders is undeniably political. It is nonetheless a useful acknowledgment that some blind trusts are not really blind. But the Governor went too far in throwing out all such trusts. Properly used, they can be valuable.   Mr. Florio's executive order followed the embarrassing disclosure that his chief of staff, Joseph Salema, owned 50 percent of a small securities firm that has built up a disproportionate share of New Jersey bond business. Federal investigators have yet to charge anyone with wrongdoing. But the governor is up for re-election, and hardly needs a scandal in his outer office. So his chief aide is gone, and Mr. Florio is hastily tightening ship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helping Children Beat the Odds Against Them; Harriet Tubman School in Newark Thrives, but Only by Working Outside the System
nytimes_articles.abstract: When a panel of experts recently described the Harriet Tubman Elementary School as an "island of excellence," it was referring to education in a city where too many public schools get failing grades.   But the characterization was apt for another reason. Physically and socially, Tubman is as isolated as any island, a 19th-century pile of red brick on South 10th Street, just north of what remains of the Springfield Avenue shopping district. From any vantage point across weed-choked lots or from windows of the occasional row house, Tubman stands alone, a redoubt against a sea of urban problems -- and arguably one of the best-run elementary schools in the state.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Co-op Apartment Corporations;
I.R.S. Suspends Audits in a Tax Case
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In anticipation of possible changes by Congress in the way that cooperative apartment corporations are taxed, the Internal Revenue Service has instructed its field offices to suspend audits of cases related to Section 277 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Up to now, the I.R.S. has contended that residential co-op corporations are liable under Section 277 for additional taxes on income from such sources as laundry rooms and interest on reserve funds. If the I.R.S.'s contention is upheld, most co-ops around the country could wind up owing thousands of dollars or more in back taxes and penalties.

nytimes_articles.headline: Battle Over Japanese Politics May Force Election
nytimes_articles.abstract: The long-running fight over cleaning up Japan's scandal-plagued electoral system has broken out into open political warfare, increasing the likelihood that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa will be forced to dissolve the Parliament and call an early election.   Some senior ruling party members said the outcome of this furious struggle was still in doubt, but today most Japanese news reports were predicting that an announcement from Mr. Miyazawa dissolving the Parliament would be made this afternoon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Impossible mission: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the event of U.S. military intervention, Bosnia will be much like Vietnam. The soldiers who are sent there will get themselves killed in record numbers. Those who don't die will receive the world's scorn when it turns out that they are unable to accom

nytimes_articles.headline: A Serious Fratello Takes Cavaliers Job
nytimes_articles.abstract: MIKE FRATELLO , the former Atlanta Hawks coach who became a TV analyst on National Basketball Association broadcasts, was hired yesterday as coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers. Fratello succeeds LENNY WILKENS , who resigned May 24 after the Chicago Bulls eliminated Cleveland from the N.B.A. playoffs in four games.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cruel to Substitutes
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Comparing President Clinton to a substitute teacher in "Settle Down -- and Toughen Up" (editorial, June 8) was brilliant. I vividly remember poor old Mrs. Bones trying to control my fourth-grade class. She looked about 90 years old and as if she weighed in at about 80 pounds. The class was totally in control the minute she walked in the door.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Howardena Pindell'  'Abstraction as Metaphor 1972-1992'   Kenkeleba House  214-216 East Second Street  Lower East Side  Through June 23  'Howardena Pindell' 'Social and Political Work 1980-1993'   Alternative Museum  594 Broadway, at Houston Street  SoHo  Through Wednesday    In her prolific career, Howardena Pindell has moved from work that relies on formal nuances to a passionate involvement with questions of identity and politics. These two shows trace the evolution of Ms. Pindell's art over the last 20 years, with Kenkeleba House offering a retrospective of her earlier paintings and collages, while the Alternative Museum features later works on political and social themes.

nytimes_articles.headline: 77-Trombone Requiem
nytimes_articles.abstract: In honor of Father's Day, Wendy Mae Chambers's "Mass for Mass Trombones: A Requiem for 77 Trombones" is to be performed tomorrow at 9 P. M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. The nine-movement work, dedicated to the composer's father, is constructed from the 13th-century Mass for the Dead. The audience will be surrounded by 11 choirs of seven trombones each, conducted by David Gilbert. Thomas Hutchinson is to perform a solo from the pulpit. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 662-2133.

nytimes_articles.headline: TV Weekend; Dostoyevsky by Way of Jeremy Irons
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeremy Irons was in town this week, being celebrated for his work not in film, as outstanding as it is, but in television. The Museum of Television and Radio decided, quite rightly, to focus on Mr. Irons's performances going back to the 1970's in "Love for Lydia" and continuing through, among other productions, "Brideshead Revisited" (1980-81) and "Tales From Hollywood" (1992). Not so coincidentally, Mr. Irons can be seen doing an especially intense turn on Bravo tomorrow night, at 7 and at 1:30 A.M., in the American premiere of the BBC production of "The Dream" (1990).    Adapted by Murray Watts from "The Dream of a Ridiculous Man," Dostoyevsky's last short story, "The Dream" is a monologue. The Man -- admittedly, I'm always suspicious of characters called the Anything, but here it works -- sits in a mansionlike setting that could be either a home or an insane asylum. And he talks, directly to the camera. Staying remarkably close to the story, the Irons character begins by admitting that "I am a ridiculous man," something he has known since the moment he was born. Then he tells us of the night, one November, when he decided to kill himself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Careers Close To Coming Full Circle
nytimes_articles.abstract: One has lasted 11 seasons; the other has toiled for 10. They were born role players, Trent Tucker the spot-up shooter, Darrell Walker the dogged defender. They came to the Knicks a year apart, first-round draft picks at the boot camp of a drill sergeant named Hubie Brown.   If they could have merged their skills somehow, become one player, the coach might have had something nice to say. Tucker was too passive to suit him. Walker was too wild. Sometimes it was as if their mere existence got under his skin.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Court Decisions Vanish From the Record
nytimes_articles.abstract: The lawsuit drags on for years. Finally, the court reaches a decision. Then suddenly, a few months later, the ruling all but vanishes, precluded from ever being used as a precedent in future cases. What happened?   Chances are, the losing party and the winner have struck a deal: in exchange for an extra sum or some other consideration, the winner agrees to ask the judge or an appeals court to issue an order "vacating" the decision, as if it had never existed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankees' Owner Revives Talk of Moving His Team
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Steinbrenner's on-again, off-again love affair with the Bronx may be off again, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.   The owner of the New York Yankees, who has threatened several times over the last decade to abandon the team's home in the Bronx, is unhappy again and is talking about exploring other potential sites for his baseball team, the Governor and his top economic adviser said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Magic Suit Continues
nytimes_articles.abstract: The woman who says MAGIC JOHNSON gave her the virus that causes AIDS won't let public disclosure of her name force her to abandon her $2 million lawsuit against the former Los Angeles Lakers star, her spokesman said.   United States District Judge RICHARD A. ENSLEN in Kalamazoo, Mich., retitled the lawsuit yesterday to include WAYMER MOORE's name. The pseudonym Jane Doe had been used on court documents since the lawsuit was filed in October. Enslen initially had ordered the woman's identity be withheld to protect her 5-year-old daughter. But Enslen reversed his decision after Johnson's attorneys argued last month that keeping her name confidential was hindering their case as they tried to learn of her sexual history.

nytimes_articles.headline: Giuliani Backs Rights On Abortion
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose 1989 campaign for mayor at times became bogged down in questions about his commitment to abortion rights, sought yesterday to remove the issue from his 1993 campaign by emphatically endorsing a woman's right to choose abortion without limitations.   Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, made his statement at a breakfast meeting organized by his wife, Donna Hanover Giuliani, who as a television news anchor was always Donna Hanover but like another political wife is now asking for an appellation evolution.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; Change Is Hard
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bill Clinton ran as the candidate of change. So, in his way, did Ross Perot. A large majority of Americans voted for them and for change.
